mil3.8:0.1_0: The Simile of the Making Hand
mil3.8:0.2_0: There’s questions that are to be answered with a counter-question.
mil3.8:1.1_0: A senior monk who brought the following:
mil3.8:1.3_0: “Sir, I do know that the first part of the night is getting late, and leave the royal compound. What’s fallen into trouble.”
mil3.8:2.10_0: In the same way, even if I live at home I’m not managed by a living at home, I’m still stable.
mil3.8:2.11_0: If I had gone forth from the lay life to homelessness, I’m not able to live for a long time.”
mil3.8:2.2_0: “We teach the teacher. Don’t understand his teacher’s doctrine, the student, and the astute person who understands that.”
mil3.8:2.3_0: Because of that, when the king’s wife was content with any kind of remainder, he has been brought for those senior monks, from the groups of eight, and it’s allowable for him to do the invitation procedure; that’s not the attendant.
mil3.8:2.6_0: “How do you believe in this way?
mil3.8:2.7_0: ‘Have I lost my confidence in my heart, just because I am a king’s confidence.’
mil3.8:2.9_0: “Sir, like a lion, king of beasts, just keeps it outside the monastic boundary mark.
mil3.8:3.1_0: And then Nāgadatta got up from his seat and went to King Pajjota.
mil3.8:3.2_0: And soon after the dragon had left, Nāgadatta thought,
mil3.8:3.3_0: “What have I declared with the dragon?”
mil3.8:3.5_0: “I’ve already been led on by Nāgadatta, sir, and I’ve finished with all sensual pleasures.”
mil3.8:3.7_0: “What has I asked by the King?”
mil3.8:3.9_0: “I’ve learned all that spreads in a driverage. I’ve broken through all state.”
mil3.8:4.1_0: Then when the night had passed, Nāgadatta robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the king’s home, and sat down on the seat spread out.
mil3.8:4.2_0: And the king said to him,
mil3.8:5.1_0: “Don’t ask him a question, Kūṭadanta. It’s not that I’ve committed the rest of that night when I’ve passed away.
mil3.8:5.3_0: ‘What has I asked, sir? What is the point of falling? What is, for me to be quite different?’”
mil3.8:6.2_0: “Great king, it’s not easy to see the king that’s spent the night in happiness.
mil3.8:6.3_0: For what it was short, I thought,
mil3.8:6.4_0: ‘What’s the finest lady in Mithilā? What’s the point of giving that which I use to be relinquished? What can I agree with what is well spoken?’”
mil3.8:7.1_0: The Book of the Gos is finished.
